Message.Msg: "There is a clear multiyear trend on ROIC, which clearly demonstrates that Amazon is blah, blah, blah..." That's exactly why you shorted from $180 and the stock is approaching $280 strongly against your investing thesis. You cherry pick the inappropriate "multiyear" timeframes. The share price is not based on a timeframe held strictly to the years you happen to select from the recent past. It is based on recent years plus a projection out into future years which should yield the large returns which will be the results of those past investments. If just to illustrate you have Year 1 at -5 and Year 2 at - 10 in the past, but Year X some years beyond that at +30 or +40 and even larger returns subsequent to that year, it makes no sense to have cherry picked only Year 1 and 2 in order to have evaluated the life-time value of the investment.

Topic.Title: Tech, have you changed your tune, and why?

Message.Msg: It's actually more akin to non-equilibrium economics with quasi rational actors. The real world as opposed to tautologies... Flows must balance for a stable equilibrium. Real growth is dropping because we are trying to maintain an unsustainable state. The deadweight loss will grow and the return on capital will turn solidly negative within 2 years. Likely sooner. China knows this and is planning for it. We are engaging in the biggest confidence game of all time because we are not being intellectually honest about the underlying drivers and fundamentals. We are afraid to confront the brutal reality. Once we do, this country will ascend again. But, instead we are encouraging more malonvestment every day...

"Again, I challenge you to put specific and real numbers ... " When the investment thesis involves future there can be no "real" numbers. Those looking for them wind up like you, frustrated. What the market does is simply look at Amazon's track record of going for several years into investment programs that begin with losses and end with multiple years of huge profits. So it isn't measuring by isolated strings of annual ROIC but rather multiple years of investment expansion followed by large returns in multiple years. If you haven't figured that out in the past numbers, then my posting anything is not going to change your mind. You're simply too lazy to look at the SEC filings over that long a period. I challenge you to put up specific numbers that refute what I have described above. "(TGT, WMT matching), state tax collection shifts the mix in adverse ways (both product and channel). That's just to start." Ha! What a joke. Brick and mortar are simply showrooms for Amazon. Even those retailers you name are going the way of BKS and BBY. I guess you didn't realize that Walmart is essential flat in marketshare gains during the past 3 years. Factoring in inflation, Walmart's growth over that stretch is probably NEGATIVE. And over a 5 year period, as Amazon more than tripled its share of retail with 225% growth vs. 18% for Walmart. Again, factoring in inflation, Walmart grew by only 1-2% per year during that time or essentially flat. Now that Amazon can move right next to where customers live it is going to cut even further into brick and mortar share.

What could those other companies be doing wrong? Why are they shutting down stores left and right? They're NOT GROWING, and they're not making huge or even positive margins either!

No, because people who feel pressures like than on discretionary spending usually cut out of their budgets things like vacations and restaurants and joy rides around town to the mall and wind up staying home. But their spending rarely goes to zero. From home you can still want to something, and you can order so frictionlessly from Amazon. The same has always happened in the past when oil prices went up. Amazon sales just increased. Didn't help shorts at all. And then when people get used to it the pent up demand hits and they go out and spend more and more at Amazon anyway. Over the past 5 years oil prices did not go down and yet Amazon revenue grew 225%. Shorts simply can't do math if they think oil prices are a useful thing to them.

Message.Msg: " oil prices have gone from $10 in 1998 to almost $100 today" And Amazon's sales have gone from $0.05 to $50 billion. (Yawn.) Diminish? More people keep coming and more kinds of products offered and bought. If diminish means going from $0.05 to $50 billion instead of to $51 billion (for now) how did that help shorts who were "right" about it slowing growth? Sure it slowed, but only in relative terms, $50 billion instead of $51. lol! Profit model? The near-term object is growth, which entails heavy spending. Just as with the last expansion cycle shorts won't know what hit them when the huge, huge profits are produced at the end of the cycle.

I'm a fan of Sybil and Techstrategy. They are worth reading I believe they made a lot of money going short NFLX, CMG, PCLN and a few others. That said, it's hard to believe Sybil is making money short AMZN, since I am still down in my positions, and I was hedged (by selling puts aginst my short) ! This is a very professional way that institutions trim down their positions without tanking the SP.

Topic.Title: yes, revenue its up, profits have went toward 0, many of the spends are "capitalized" so profits shouldn't go to 0

Message.Msg: "Those costs are amortized and depreciated over time, not a one time income statement" Oh, sure they're one time-in this sense: They don't operate at anything near optimum efficiency and full capacity in year one or two. And they're very rapidly capitalized so there is no one to one correspondence between a single year's earnings and the proportion of the cost that gets amortized. As previously, by the time they're running closer to full capacity, so little if any depreciation as a % of sales will be being amortized resulting in huge, huge profits that will astound the tiny imaginations of you skeptics. You'd have thought shorts had figured that out by now. But they don't. They remain as clueless about depreciation as they ever were.
great report

Lol, you have such a good argument style Nemesis. When confronted with facts, you just go with" blah blah." Ok so you pick the time frame, how many years going back would AMZN's profits reach what target makes in a year, $3 billion this year, so we need to go back all the way to 2008, between 2008-2012 in 5 years, AMZN made the $3.4 Billion in profits. During those years, TGT made $12 billion in profits. "So funny! CC, BGP, BBY, BKS once had "profits" too. Then they got Amazoned. Why would anyone think Target will be any different? " AMZN with it's tax advantage was able to bankrupt several firms, now places where they are charging taxes, companies like best buy are coming back. I know you don't like facts, but this is the case.

They failed to mention how Amazon's number kills Apple's on FB. And the author could not figure out that Amazon's own website IS a social network. In contrast, a Website like Walmart's is just not that interesting and outside of making the occasional purchase does not have much if any community of reviewers and discussion boards compared to Amazon.

Topic.Title: yes, revenue its up, profits have went toward 0, many of the spends are "capitalized" so profits shouldn't go to 0

Message.Msg: Why don't you try adding in all the off balance sheet operating leases... AWS related investments will have 2-3 years useful lives as technology infrastructure has exceptionally short useful lives. In fact, Amazon is at a disadvantage in its historical buildout because the new Haswell based servers have far better energy/performance tradeoffs and energy (including cooling to move the server heat out...) is a very material portion of the TCO... And the prices Amazon can charge is capped by price matching from competitors. Where it used to have a 5-10% tax subsidy, it is losing that in the most populous states... And you are plain stupid in your comment on energy cost... I'll tear that to shreds later.

Thanks Jeff. I try to stay above the pathetic #$%$ that GeeGee, Nas and others engage in. Fact based analysis here augmented with an understanding of competitive strategy / dynamics. The fundamental economics are moving against Amazon and Bezos knows it...

Topic.Title: yes, revenue its up, profits have went toward 0, many of the spends are "capitalized" so profits shouldn't go to 0

Message.Msg: Singular focus on growth rather than profitable growth has led to massive malinvestment and has made Amazon unnecessarily vulnerable to tail risk as it has loaded up on leverage -- far more than most realize (fulfillment center leases, vendor financing and extension of days payable and customer commitments...). The right macro shock and Amazon becomes insolvent.

Now, some have figured about a script based method. They'll get theirs in time...
I guess you haven't read GeeGees and NASDAQ600's posts. Or are you one of them? or are you all one and the same?

For a nanosecond, I thought you might have it in you to think a little more rigorously. Yes, digital and physical are in fact different... But, then you have to get more micro... You almost started to segment the categories and understand that the cost drivers depend upon product, category and customer characteristics. But, then you blew it... NFLX already has significant market penetration and has broader selection than Amazon (the tail). In terms premium content, the choice of going to Target for video is a false choice. OTT video is already available for anyone with cable. Hulu, VUDU, CinemaNow, YouTube premium... There are plenty of choices. Simply not going to capture the economic rents embedded in this stock price.

Message.Title: Go ahead and open more warehouses.

That's the great thing about being a pumper for a "story stock", especially one like Amazon that keeps shifting the story as it becomes clear the economics won't work on the past ones... I will be putting out real analysis that shows that the economics of expansion are destroying value. Rather than BS about margins, when one looks at the true tradeoff embedded in geographic expansion (more capex, inventory carrying cost and fulfillment opex versus transportation cost savings), you can show that it is NOT providing claimed leverage... (though part of the effect is just expanding into products and categories where the underlying economics were never going to be compelling...). ROIC dropping, Inventory turns dropping. Gross shipping cost as a % of revenue increasing and net only dropping because of transfer revenue from Prime. This will rate with Enron in time...

Message.Title: Amazon math - solution for the world problem
Message.Msg: Have you ever heard of running a cloud business on farms of machines, switches, storage that need power, maintenance, network, people and yet it cost nothing on the balance sheet? Welcome to Amazon math. They have come up with a new accounting practice call Amazon math where you only add the revenue and do not subtract expenses. And all those analysts out there love it, they cheer it and they bump up the price target on your stock based on what else? Amazon Math Now, we can extend this concept to US government and stop subtracting deficit from GDP and whoa, we have surplus, spend, spend, spend... thanks to the Amazon math. I wonder why S&P did not use this math when they downgraded US credit rating.

Message.Title: Jeff bezos sale shares in last 5 years- $1.3 billion
Message.Msg: He has made three big sells in the last 5 years, 2008- 4 Million shares for $303M, 2010 almost 8 million shares for $793M and in 2012 800K shares for $201 Million. In 2006 he had 101M in shares, now he has 87M in shares remaining. Compare the amount Bezos has made from his sales to that to how much AMZN has made in profits since it's inception 17 years ago, $1.9 billion.... And that is just Bezos since 2008, I am pretty sure all insider sales since inception is much higher than the $1.9 Billion. AMZN insiders would have suffered terribly if AMZN was a private firm, where profits mattered.

Message.Msg: As someone who has looked at CMG's economics closely, it has the best unit economics in the restaurant industry. As healthcare costs grow wrt total, I'd be more comfortable holding CMG than the other domestics. MCD is the safest play because it functions as a currency and inflation hedge and the royalty stream has less risk. CMG certainly wouldn't be my pick to short based upon fundamentals right now. I'm about to enter several restaurant shorts (via LT puts) though...
